awd_titl_txt: SemiSynBio: Collaborative Research: YeastOns: Neural Networks Implemented in Communicating Yeast Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Large, three-dimensional cell colonies grown inexpensively using simple raw materials could be made into cheap, energy-efficient computers. A fundamental challenge in using living cells for computing is that computation by cells is error prone, and cells divide, die and reorganize inside a cell culture, making it difficult to maintain a defined architecture. This research will explore the design of yeast cell-based computing systems inspired by how computing is performed by the animal brain cells. To develop new knowledge at the intersection of electronics, computing and biology will require a new generation of students familiar with each of these areas who can work in collaborative teams. Building on work with organizations including the Freshman Research Initiative at UT Austin and Women in Science and Engineering at JHU, the PIs will develop programs to allow groups of undergraduate researchers to engage in long term research programs in which students have the opportunity to perform independent investigations as part of collaborative, inter-university teams.

This project will combine ideas from computer architecture and systems neuroscience with new tools from synthetic biology to develop yeastons - Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells that can collectively emulate a feedforward neural network through engineered cell-cell communication processes and programmable transcriptional logic. Crucially, yeaston networks will be designed to tolerate the inherent noisiness of single-cell biomolecular information processing and require no specific higher order spatial organization or patterning. The project members will build new protein receptors for small molecule signals and genetic logic systems that will enable single yeastons to emulate nodes in a feedforward neural network. The input-output behavior of single yeastons and yeaston networks will be quantitatively characterized, making it possible to evaluate the potential for scalable computation in yeaston systems. High-level models from neuroscience will be used to develop design principles for assembling robust yeaston networks and to derive scaling laws for yeaston computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Context: In nature, many different cell types collaborate to create complex communities, organisms, and even ecosystems. Enabling this is the ability, by each cell in a system, to send signals, respond to signals, and make internal biochemically instantiated decisions about how to contribute to the whole. This amazing quality of multi-cellular systems (that they emerge from simple low level interactions) can lead to staggering complexity, which if harnessed could enable engineers to someday build robust multi-cellular factories, immune systems, and biologically implemented diagnostics. However, the challenge is to build an engineering framework for designing, building, and testing cells so that they can send and receive chemical signals, so that their internal genetic circuits function as designed, and rests on a solid and scalable mathematical foundation. 

With this award, we created such a framework based on engineered yeast cells. First, by exploring the chemical signalling repertoire of nature and in particular of yeast itself, we designed a number of new modular signalling pathways that could be used to provide chemical input and output "wires" to coordinate multi-cellular systems. Second, we designed new genetic circuits that process these signals, to allow the cells in a multi-cellular system to make decisions. Third, we demonstrated a series of multi-cellular circuits based on these components ranging from simple inverters to complex bistable systems. Pervading all of this work is a modular design framework that associates a mathematical description of the behavior of each cell type and, in particular, that supports composition, allowing us to predict the behavior of an assemblage of cell types from their individual descriptions.

More broadly, we believe the technology we developed will enable most robust control of biologics manufacturing, tissue engineering, and could have a number of other industrial and biomedical applications. Furthermore, the mathematical framework we developed is very generic, and will form the basis for other engineering efforts that use different cells types and signalling systems. Finally, this award allowed us to develop educational material and experiences that have improved our ability to train synthetic biologists. 


Last Modified: 02/09/2022
Modified by: Eric Klavins

Inspired by electrical circuits, we designed yeast to distribute computation and communicate information to generate biological algorithms
